Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Study of Low Volume Solder Interconnects for 3D Integrated Circuit Packaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Moore's Law, which predicts that the number of transistors in an integrated circuit doubles approximately every two years, has been a major driver for the US economy for decades. Unfortunately, technological and fundamental challenges associated with continued device shrinking make the current rate of progress unsustainable. Recently, 3D integrated circuit technology has emerged as a leading approach to keep up with Moore's Law by stacking chips rather than by shrinking device dimensions. To achieve 3D integration, new joining technologies for interconnection and stacked bonding must be developed. Bonding by low volume solder interconnects is specially promising due to their good electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties. This collaborative research award supports fundamental research to obtain the knowledge needed for the development of low volume solder interconnects. Research results will not only help realize the full potential of this new bonding technique in 3D integrated circuit packaging, but also be used to improve joining methodologies important in the aerospace and nuclear power industries and in power electronics and thermal management applications. Moreover, the project will help establish an effective collaboration between the two PIs who are both from underrepresented groups.

The small dimensions of low volume solder interconnects make it possible for the solder joints to solidify isothermally through the formation of intermetallic compounds at the expense of the liquid solders. This technique, also known as Transient Liquid Phase Bonding, allows the formation of a joint at temperatures lower than the expected operating conditions, minimizing damage to the temperature-sensitive components of the circuits from overheating. However, the small dimensions of low volume solder interconnects lead to large current densities during operation. These large current densities induce large electrical, thermal, and mechanical driving forces which give rise to complex microstructural processes. This research aims to advance the fundamental understanding of the complex microstructure processes in low volume solder interconnects, in particular about the important microscopic mechanisms governing processing-microstructure-property-performance relationships. The research team will develop an integrated multi-physics phase field modeling and perform systematic simulation studies of the microstructure formation and evolution during processing, operation, and damage of low volume solder interconnects. The simulations will be used to correlate macroscopic processing parameters and operating conditions to microscopic phenomena involving diffusion, current flow, heat transfer and stress concentration, and elucidate the mechanisms of defect formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three dimensional (3D) integrated circuit technology has emerged as a leading approach to keeping up with Moor’s Law by stacking chips to overcome the difficulties in further shrinking device dimensions. To achieve 3D integrated circuit, new joining technologies for interconnection and stacked bonding must be developed. Bonding by low volume interconnects is specially promising due to their good electrical, thermal and mechanical properties. The small diffusion distances in low volume interconnects make it possible for the solder joints to solidify isothermally through the formation of intermetallic compounds at the expense of the liquid solders at temperature much lower than the maximum operating temperature, minimizing damage to temperature sensitive devices. However, the short length scale causes challenges associated with the underlying complicated microstructure processes under aggravated electrical, thermal and mechanical conditions, which involve microstructure evolutions and microvoid formation leading to material failure. This project offers modeling and simulation studies of low volume interconnects to advance fundamental understanding of microstructure processes that impact the performance and reliability.

 Intellectual Merit:

Complementing the computational studies (by the collaborating PI’s group at Texas A&M University) of joint formation through liquid solder solidification to investigate the effects of joining parameters on the microstructures of low volume interconnects, modeling and simulations (by the PI’s group at Michigan Technological University) of microstructure evolutions under macroscopic operating conditions are carried out to correlate the highly heterogeneous and anisotropic nature of the low volume interconnects to the defect structure evolutions. Multi-physics modeling of internal chemical, mechanical, electrical and thermal processes is developed to address concurrent and coupled mass diffusion, current flow, heat transfer and stress concentration phenomena. The Ohm’s law, elastic equilibrium equation, and general heat conduction equation are solved in time-evolving local microstructural heterogeneities and anisotropy conditions in one unified computational framework to account for the mass diffusion driven by microstructure dependent electric field, stress gradient, and temperature gradient. The effects of important controlling factors of the microstructure evolutions are analyzed, including the material specific thermodynamic and kinetic properties and the geometrical considerations of interconnects. The simulations also reveal the important roles of the grain structures in electromigration behaviors of precipitates and pores in tin-based alloys, which are neglected in solder joints of bigger dimensions but become significant when the dimensions of low volume interconnects are not much greater than the grain size. The findings provide insights into the microscopic mechanisms for processing-microstructure-performance relationships that is of importance in low volume interconnect development for 3D integrated circuit packaging.

 Broader Impact:

The project has created learning opportunities and research positions for three domestic graduate students to conduct their graduate research focusing on microstructure evolutions in crystalline materials, and built a collaboration relationship for the PI’s group with Professor Arroyave’s group at Texas A&M University. Student presentations were delivered at TMS, MS&T, IMECE, and the MSE department seminar series. The research opportunity motivated a woman undergraduate participant to attend graduate school at Michigan Tech. The research outcomes of this project have also been presented to high school students during MTU’s Summer Youth Programs.


Last Modified: 06/30/2019
Modified by: Yongmei M Jin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Three dimensional (3D) integrated circuit technology has emerged as a leading approach to keeping up with Moor?s Law by stacking chips to overcome the difficulties in further shrinking device dimensions. To achieve 3D integrated circuit, new joining technologies for interconnection and stacked bonding must be developed. Bonding by low volume interconnects is specially promising due to their good electrical, thermal and mechanical properties. The small diffusion distances in low volume interconnects make it possible for the solder joints to solidify isothermally through the formation of intermetallic compounds at the expense of the liquid solders at temperature much lower than the maximum operating temperature, minimizing damage to temperature sensitive devices. However, the short length scale causes challenges associated with the underlying complicated microstructure processes under aggravated electrical, thermal and mechanical conditions, which involve microstructure evolutions and microvoid formation leading to material failure. This project offers modeling and simulation studies of low volume interconnects to advance fundamental understanding of microstructure processes that impact the performance and reliability. Multi-physics modeling of internal chemical, mechanical, electrical and thermal processes is developed to address concurrent and coupled mass diffusion, current flow, heat transfer and stress concentration phenomena. The Ohm?s law, elastic equilibrium equation, and general heat conduction equation are solved in time-evolving local microstructural heterogeneities and anisotropy conditions in one unified computational framework to account for the mass diffusion driven by microstructure dependent electric field, stress gradient, and temperature gradient. The effects of important controlling factors of the microstructure evolutions are analyzed, including the material specific thermodynamic and kinetic properties and the geometrical considerations of interconnects.
